div1.p: Kean supports offering pensions for those who took part in the Reed Yellow Fever demonstration, and for the widows of those who died. He also supports a pension for Agramonte for his important contribution to the Board. [Courtesy of The Albert and Shirley Small Special Collections Library, University of Virginia Library]

div1.head: Memorandum from Jefferson Randolph Kean to Merritte W. Ireland, February 2, 1928
div1.p:
SUBJECT:- Pensions for those taking part in the Reed Yellow
Fever Demonstration, and the Widows of those who died.
In reply to letter of Hon. J. Mayhew Wainwright, M.C.

In the autumn of 1902 the demonstration by Walter Reed and
his assistants of the transmission of yellow fever by the house
mosquito (then called Culex Fascitus, but now called Aedes Egypti)
had been accepted quite generally by scientific men and the City of
Havana had been cleared of yellow fever by the application of
this discovery. It then seemed to the Secretary of War to be the
time to consider the question of awards for this extraordinary
scientific work, attended as it was by danger to all taking part
in it, and illness and loss of life to some. The Secretary of
War, Mr. Elihu Root, accordingly recommended in his annual report
to the President that steps be taken to promote Major Walter Reed
from the grade he then held to that of Colonel, and promote Major
William C. Gorgas to the grade of Lieutenant Colonel. Before
this recommendation could be carried out Reed died, November 23,
1902, without having received any reward. The promotion recommended
for him was given to Gorgas.

A bill was prepared in this office recommending that Congress
grant to his widow,who was left with only a small life insurance,
as a pension the monthly pay he was receiving at the time of his
death, $300.00. This amount, however, was reduced when
considered by the Senate Committee to $125.00 per month, which was
for some years provided in the Army appropriation bill. A like amount
was given to the widow of Dr. Jesse W. Lazear, who lost his life in
the course of this work. Dr. James Carroll, who was a contract
surgeon, was given a commission in the regular medical corps, and
was, before his death, promoted to the grade of Major. After his
death in September, 1907 his wife was given the same annuity with
the other two widows ($125.00 per month)

John R. Kissinger, a private in the Army Hospital Corps, one
of the first volunteers to offer himself for experiment in this
demonstration, and who contracted a severe case of yellow fever, was,
in 1907, given a pension of $12.00 per month, his health having failed
him so that he was unable to work. Later this pension was increased to
$100.00 per month, which he is now receiving.

Another of the volunteers who suffered an attack of experimental
yellow fever, Clyde L. West, at that time also a private in the
Hospital Corps, was given a like pension of $100.00 per month by
Congress last year.

The above mentioned are the only recipients of any pension or reward
from the U.S. government for their part in this great work, although a
number of others took part in it. A full list of these with the
part taken by each as shown by the official records are published in
Senate Document #10, 59th Congress, second session. This document
consists of a memorandum for the President from The Surgeon General
R.M. O'Reilley, which was forwarded to the Senate and House of Repre-
sentatives with a special message by the President which was as follows:

“The enclosed papers are transmitted to Congress in the earnest
hope that it will take suitable action in the matter. Major Reed's
part in the experiments which resulted in teaching us how to cope with
yellow fever was such as to render mankind his debtor, and this nation
should in some proper fashion bear witness of this fact. Theodore
Roosevelt, White House, December 5, 1906.”

In my opinion Congress has failed to carry out the recommendation
of the President “to take suitable action in the matter.” I consider
that the pensions given were not suitable to meet the necessities of
the recipients, or to adequately award so great a work. Since they
were given, however, the inadequancy has been greatly augmented by the
increase in the cost of living, and the inflation of currency caused
by the World War, which have practically reduced their purchasing power
and value one half. It seems evident the pensions now being given
should all be doubled, and as other claimants arise as participators in
this work they should be considered in like manner in accordance with
the merits of each.

Only one member of the Board of Medical Officer conducting these
experiments remains alive; this is Dr. Aristides Agramonte, who is
now Professor in the medical school of the University of Havana.
Dr. Agramonte was born in Cuba during the ten years' war for independence
fought by the Cubans against Spain. In this war, his father, a Cuban
officer was killed in battle, and his family removed to the United States
while he was still a small boy. He was educated in New York and
graduated in medicine from the College of Physicians and Surgeons in
1892. He served for a number of years in the medical corps of the army
as Acting Assistant Surgeon, and as such wasas appointed a member of the
General Ireland
-3-
Board of Medical Officers headed by Major Walter Reed which was sent to
Cuba to study yellow fever. This board was appointed by special order
122, A.G.O., Washington, May 24, 1900. Dr. Agramonte took a very
important part in the work of the Board. (See note) The fact that
he is now a citizen of Cuba in no way diminishes the obligation of
the United States to recognise and appropriately reward the work
which he did while serving in the U. S. army. I would recommend
that he be given a gold medal struck by order of Congress in commemora-
tion,of the work of the Board of which he was a member, and that this
medal be given also to the heir of each of the deceased members of the
Board; also, that Dr. Aristides Agramonte be given an annuity equal
to that given to the widows of the deceased members of the Board, and
that this annuity be made payable, in the event of his death, to his
widow during her life.

NOTE: I am informed by the officer who prepared the memorandum for
the President published in Senate Document #10 referred to above, that
in his opinion the statement of Dr. Agramonte's share in the work made
in that memorandum does not do justice to Dr. Agramonte. This statement
was based upon information believed by the officer to be reliable, but
which was afterwards found to be inaccurate. When Dr. Agramonte's
attention was called to Senate Document #10 he made a protest against
the injustice done him, but there seemed to be at that time no way to
correct it.
